column1: Barnsley Football Club is a professional football club in Barnsley
column2: South Yorkshire
column3: England
column4: which plays in the Championship
column5: the second tier of English football.  Nicknamed "the Tykes"
column6: they were founded in 1887 by Reverend Tiverton Preedy. The club's colours were originally blue
column7: but were converted to red and white in 1904. Their home ground since 1888 has been Oakwell.

column1: Barnsley won the FA Cup in 1912 and were runners-up in 1910. The club won the 2016 Football League Trophy
column2: beating Oxford United 3–2 in the final
column3: and the 2016 Football League play-offs
column4: beating Millwall 3–1 in the final.

column2: a majority stake in the club was sold to a consortium involving Chien Lee of NewCity Capital
column3: Grace Hung and Paul Conway of Pacific Media Group
column4: Indian businessman Neerav Parekh and baseball legend Billy Beane. Barnsley's rivals include Sheffield Wednesday
column5: Sheffield United

column1: Barnsley have spent more seasons in the second tier of English football than any other club in history and have produced some notable talents over the years who have gone on to be successful at other clubs. One example is Tommy Taylor
column2: who was a prolific goalscorer for Barnsley in the early 1950s and went on to win two league titles with Manchester United (as well as scoring 16 times in 19 England internationals) before losing his life in the Munich air disaster. Taylor's move to Manchester United was for a fee of £29
column3: 999 – one of the highest fees in England at the time. Taylor broke into the Barnsley team just after the sale of wing-half Danny Blanchflower to Aston Villa. Blanchflower would go on to sign for Tottenham Hotspur and be voted FWA Player of the Year twice as well as captaining the North London club to the first league and cup double of the 20th century.

column1: Barnsley FC was established in 1887 by a clergyman
column2: Tiverton Preedy
column3: and played in the Sheffield and District League from 1890 and then in the Midland League from 1895. They joined the Football League in 1898
column4: and struggled in the Second Division for the first decade
column5: due in part to ongoing financial difficulties. In 1910 the club reached the FA Cup final
column6: where they lost out to Newcastle United in a replay match. However
column7: they would then reach the 1912 FA Cup Final where they would defeat West Bromwich Albion 1–0 in a replay to win the trophy for the first time in their history.

column1: When the league restarted after the First World War
column2: the 1919–20 season brought some significant changes to the league. The principal difference was that the First Division would be increased from 20 teams to 22. The bottom team from the previous season was Tottenham Hotspur and they were duly relegated. The first extra place in the First Division went to Chelsea
column3: who retained their place despite finishing 2nd bottom and therefore in the relegation places. Derby County and Preston North End were rightly promoted from the Second Division which left one place to be filled. Having finished the previous season's Second Division in 3rd place (1914–15)
column4: Barnsley expected to achieve First Division status for the first time
column5: but The Football League instead chose to call a ballot of the clubs. Henry Norris
column7: had recently moved Woolwich Arsenal north of the River Thames to Highbury
column8: and needed First Division football to attract fans to their new home. He was later to admit some underhand dealings
column9: allegedly including the bribing of some member clubs to vote for Arsenal's inclusion. They duly won the vote and Barnsley were consigned to the second tier of English football for another 8 decades.

column1: The club did however come close to reaching the top division in the early years. In 1922
column2: they missed out on promotion by a single goal. During the years preceding and following the Second World War
column3: the club found themselves sliding between the Second and Third Division.

column1: In 1949 the club signed a 23-year-old wing-half called Danny Blanchflower from Glentoran
column2: and he so impressed at Oakwell that two years later he was signed by First Division side Aston Villa
column3: later signing for Tottenham Hotspur and being voted FWA Player of the Year twice
column4: as well as being the captain of the 20th century's first league and cup double winning team in 1961.

column1: Around the time of Blanchflower's departure
column2: a young centre-forward called Tommy Taylor broke into the Barnsley team
column3: scoring 26 goals in 44 games for Barnsley. In April 1953
column4: he became one of the most expensive players in English football at the time when Matt Busby signed him for Manchester United for a fee of £29
column5: 999. Taylor went on to be a prolific goalscorer at the highest level over the next five years
column6: winning two league titles and also scoring 16 times in 19 appearances for the England national football team
column7: before losing his life in the Munich air disaster in February 1958.

column1: When the Northern and Southern sections of the Third Division were replaced by national Third and Fourth Divisions for the 1958–59 season
column2: Barnsley were still in the Second Division
column3: but went down to the Third Division at the end of that season.

column2: Barnsley were relegated to the Football League Fourth Division for the first time
column3: winning promotion three years later. They went down to the Fourth Division again in 1972
column4: and this time stayed down for seven seasons
column5: finally returning to the Third Division in 1979.

column2: they went up again and quickly established themselves as a decent Second Division side throughout the 1980s
column3: although they still failed to clinch that elusive First Division place
column4: despite the introduction of the playoffs in the second half of the decade
column5: which gave teams finishing as low as fifth and eventually sixth the chance of winning promotion.

column1: === Division One and the Premier League ===
At the time of the creation of the FA Premier League in 1992
column2: Barnsley had been Football League members for 94 years but had still not reached the top flight. They were
column3: at least
column4: in a decent position to make that breakthrough
column5: as members of the new Division One  (as the old Second Division was now called). In December 1989
column7: manager of Manchester City's promotion-winning side the previous campaign
column8: to guide them into the top flight
column9: but he left nearly four years later with promotion still to be achieved. Machin's successor Viv Anderson spent just one season in charge before quitting to become Bryan Robson's assistant at Middlesbrough
column10: and for the 1994–95 season Barnsley turned to veteran midfielder Danny Wilson to manage the club.

column1: Wilson's first season brought a sixth-place finish in Division One
column2: which would normally have meant a playoff place
column3: but a restructuring of the league meant that they missed out. They finished 10th a year later before finally emerging as serious promotion contenders in the 1996–97 season
column4: finally clinching runners-up spot and automatic promotion and gaining the top flight place that they had spent 99 years trying to win.

column1: Barnsley lasted just one season in the Premier League but did not go down without a brave fight
column2: and they did reach the quarter-finals of the FA Cup
column3: famously defeating Manchester United in the fifth round. They also made their record signing that season with Gjorgi Hristov for two million pounds
column4: a record that Barnsley FC still have. Wilson then departed to take over at Sheffield Wednesday
column5: being succeeded as Barnsley manager by veteran striker John Hendrie
column6: who had been a key player in the promotion-winning team.

column1: Barnsley were the only team from outside the Premier League to reach the quarter-finals of the FA Cup in the 1998–99 season
column2: but had a disappointing season in Division One
column3: never really looking like winning promotion and eventually finishing a dismal 13th in the final table. Hendrie was then replaced as manager by Dave Bassett
column4: who rejuvenated the team and took them to fourth place in 1999–2000
column5: but they lost in the playoff final to Ipswich Town.

column1: In the following years Barnsley were not as successful
column2: with relegation to Division Two in 2002 and administration both threatening the existence of the club. Barnsley suffered greatly due to the ITV Digital crisis. A late purchase by Barnsley's then Mayor
column3: Peter Doyle
column4: saved the club from folding. Doyle has since left the club
column5: leaving Gordon Shepherd and local businessman Patrick Cryne in control. A regular turnover of managers did the club's stability no favours

column1: Barnsley had the distinction of playing in the last play-off final at Wembley before the stadium was closed for redevelopment
column2: and in 2006 won in a play-off final at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff
column3: where they beat Swansea City 4–3 on penalties (2–2 after extra-time) to earn promotion to the Championship. The manager at this time was Andy Ritchie
column4: who was in his first season in charge after replacing Paul Hart.

column1: The team struggled in their first season back in the Championship. In November 2006
column2: with Barnsley in the relegation zone
column3: Ritchie was sacked in favour of Simon Davey. Davey managed to steer the team away from relegation in the second half of the season
column4: and the eventually finished 20th. The following season
column5: a much-changed Barnsley side managed a historic FA Cup run
column6: beating Premier League giants Liverpool 2–1 at Anfield and defending champions Chelsea 1–0 to reach the semi-finals for the first time since 1912
column7: where they narrowly lost out 1–0 to fellow Championship side Cardiff City at Wembley.

column1: Barnsley narrowly avoided relegation from the Championship that season
column2: and after a disappointing start to the 2009–10 season Simon Davey. was sacked in favour of former Rotherham United boss Mark Robins.In May 2011
column3: after a difficult 2010–11 season
column4: Robins resigned as manager due to a dispute over the budget for the following season. He was replaced by Rochdale manager Keith Hill and his assistant David Flitcroft. Barnsley ended the 2011–12 season as one of only two football clubs to turn a profit in the Championship; ironically they stayed up only because Portsmouth were given a 10-point deduction for going into administration. The club's form failed to improve the following season
column5: and Keith Hill was sacked as manager shortly before the turn of the year. David Flitcroft took over initially as caretaker manager
column6: and after an improved run of results (combined with Sean O'Driscoll and Terry Butcher turning down the chance to manage the club) earned the job on a permanent basis.Barnsley won the Football League Trophy in 2016 after a 3–2 win against Oxford United of League Two. They gained promotion to the Championship following a 3–1 win over Millwall in the play-off final later that season.In September 2016
column7: Barnsley were caught up in an ongoing scandal in English football
column8: with assistant manager Tommy Wright alleged to have accepted "bungs" in exchange for working as an ambassador for a third-party player ownership consortium. Wright was initially suspended before being sacked by Barnsley.In December 2017
column9: it was announced that Patrick Cryne and family
column10: had agreed to sell an 80% stake in the club to a consortium led by Chien Lee of NewCity Capital and Pacific Media Group
column11: which is led by Paul Conway and Grace Hung. Indian investor Neerav Parekh and baseball legend Billy Beane have also bought part of the club as part of the international investor consortium.Barnsley were relegated to the third tier in 2017–18
column13: but were promoted back to the second tier the following season. In 2019–20
column14: the team avoided relegation from the division due to a 12-points deduction received by Wigan Athletic as a result of falling into administration. The second time in less than 10 years Barnsley did remain in the Championship due to other clubs going into administration. On 6 October 2020 manager Gerhard Struber left to manage the NY Red Bulls leaving his position vacant.

column2: as "Barnsley St. Peter's"

column1: 1897 – Dropped "St Peter's" to become simply Barnsley
1897–98 – Midland League runner-up. Also played in Yorkshire League
1933–34 – Football League Division Three North Champions; promoted to Division Two
1938–39 – Football League Division Three North Champions; promoted to Division Two
1939–40 – Football League programme abandoned due to outbreak of war
1953–54 – Football League Division Three North runner-up
1954–55 – Football League Division Three North Champions; promoted to Division Two
1967–68 – Football League Division Four runner-up; promoted to Division Three
1978–79 – Missed runner-up spot on goal difference; promoted to Division Three
1980–81 – Football League Division Three runner-up (on goal difference); promoted to Division Two
1990–91 – Missed play-off spot on goal difference
1992–93 – Division Two re-designated Division One on formation of FA Premier League
1996–97 – Football League runner-up; promoted to FA Premier League
1997–98 – Relegated to Football League Division One. After taking only 4 points from 19 fixtures they then went on to win 4 and draw 2 from their final 6 league matches.
1999–00 – Not promoted after play-offs. Finished 4th in the final table (Semi-final – Birmingham City 0 Barnsley 4

column1: 2008–09 – Fielded the youngest ever player in the history of the Football League at Ipswich Town when Reuben Noble-Lazarus came on aged 15 years and 45 days
2013–14 - Relegated to League One after a 3–1 defeat at Middlesbrough

2015–16 – Football League Trophy Champions after a 3–2 win against Oxford United in the final at Wembley Stadium. Promoted to Football League Championship through the 2016 Football League play-offs after finishing 6th in Football League One. Defeated Walsall in the semi finals
column2: winning 6–1 on aggregate after 3–0 first leg win and 3–1 second leg win. Defeated Millwall 3–1 in the final at Wembley Stadium.

column1: 2017–18 - Relegated to League One after a 4–1 defeat at Derby County
2018–19 - Promoted to the EFL Championship through automatic promotion
column2: after finished in second place in the 2018–19 EFL League One.

column2: Oakwell
column3: originates from the well and oak tree that were on the stadium site when first built. Oakwell is a multi-purpose sports development in Barnsley
column4: South Yorkshire
column5: used primarily by Barnsley Football Club for playing their home fixtures

column1: While the name 'Oakwell' generally refers to the main stadium
column2: it also includes several neighbouring venues which form the facilities of the Barnsley F.C. academy – an indoor training pitch
column3: a smaller stadium with seating on the south and west sides for around 2
column4: 200 spectators
column5: and several training pitches used by the different Barnsley FC squads.

column1: Until 2003 the stadium and the vast amount of land that surrounds it was owned by Barnsley Football Club themselves; however
column2: after falling into administration in 2002 the council purchased the main Oakwell Stadium to allow the club to pay its creditors and remain participants in The Football League.
'The League of Love and Hate' conducted in August 2019
column3: Barnsley supporters named fellow Yorkshire clubs Sheffield Wednesday
column4: Sheffield United and Leeds United as their biggest rivals
column5: with Huddersfield Town and Rotherham United following.

column1: Barnsley have played their home games in red shirts for most of their history. The only exception to this is the period 1887–1901
column2: where it is speculated that the team first wore blue shirts with purple/claret arms
column3: then circa 1890 the team wore chocolate and white stripes
column4: before moving on to blue and white stripes around 1898. The team first wore their now traditional red shirts in 1901.Since this time
column5: the team has worn red shirts often with a white trim. In more recent times a black trim has sometimes been used. As with most football clubs the shirt design varies from season to season. One particular design that stands out is the 1989–90 season shirt which featured white stars on a red background and has been named as one of the worst shirts ever. However
column6: the kit is fondly remembered by some fans. Sponsors names and logos were first worn in the 1980–81 season and the club has had 12 different sponsors on the shirt in total. Since manufacturers logos were added to the shirt in the 1976–77 season
column7: the club has 12 different kit manufacturers.

column2: the team has worn white shorts (sometimes with red or black trim) for their home games with the only recent exceptions coming in the early years of the 20th century. One other notable exception came in the 2000 Division One Playoff Final against Ipswich Town
column3: where the team wore red shorts
column4: thus having an all-red strip. The Reds have also worn red shorts in their 1988–89 season.

column1: Apart from the club's early years and the period 1921–1934 where the team wore black
column2: the team has worn red or white socks for its home games. Again
column3: the design changes from season to season.

column1: For 2010–11 the kit was the traditional red
column2: with white trim. It featured a shield style club badge to the left
column3: with kit sponsors Lotto's logo on the opposite side. The main design was the Barnsley Building Society eagle logo
column4: a return to the design from 2006–07.

column2: Barnsley wore the new home kit for the 2016–17 season
column3: but with black shorts.

column2: the home shirt was the traditional red
column3: with a white Puma logo and club badge on the chest area. There was a white Puma logo on each shoulder. The shorts was all white with a red Puma logo and club badge on the front. The socks was red and white hooped with a Puma logo on the knee/shin area. The socks of the upcoming 2016–17 season were very much like the socks that Barnsley wore when they were promoted to the Premier League.

column1: The club's away strip (used for away or cup fixtures where there is a clash of colours) differs from season to season but usually follows the design of the season's home strip with a variation on the colours. The most common colour for the away shirt has been white but many others have been used

column7: where the team wore the colours of the 5-time World Cup winners Brazil for their away games.
